contextId.information: "Sins" represents the punishment for sin. AT: "to take the punishment we deserved because of our sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "this ... age" represents the powers at work in the age. AT: "that he might set us free from the evil powers at work in the world today" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: that he might deliver us from this present evil age

contextId.information: The word "me" here represents what Paul was teaching. AT: "added nothing to what I teach" or "did not tell me to add anything to what I teach" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The words "to his face" are a metonym for "where he could see and hear me." AT: "I confronted him in person" or "I challenged his actions in person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I opposed him to his face

contextId.information: The word "flesh" is a metonym for effort. AT: "by your own effort" or "by your own work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The heart is metonym for the part of a person that thinks and feels. AT: "sent his Son's Spirit to show us how to think and act" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: sent the Spirit of his Son into our hearts

contextId.information: Paul is using circumcision as a metonym for being Jewish. AT: "to every person who has become a Jew" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to every man who lets himself be circumcised

contextId.information: These are metonymy for being a Jew or a non-Jew. AT: "neither being a Jew nor not being a Jew" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The cross here represents what Christ did for us when he died on the cross. AT: "the work Jesus did on the cross" or "the death and resurrection of Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
